The gifts were all loaded and Zippy, Santa’s head elf was waiting to help Santa with his deliveries.  It was a Christmas Eve like every other, so they thought."
When Santa gets stuck in a chimney, a firefighter named Nathan helps to get him out. Santa is so thankful, he asks Nathan to help them for the rest of the night.  And it’s a good thing they did.
In Santa and His Super Hero, you will read about Santa’s misadventures that Christmas evening and how his Super Hero, a fire fighter named Nathan helped him out.  The Cause - not just a Book
When we decided we were going to publish the book, we thought that we would like to help people with the sales of Santa and His Super Hero.  Since a fire fighter was so helpful to Santa that night, we thought that we would help the fire fighters. We decided that net proceeds of the sale of our book will be given to the BC Professional Fire Fighters’ Burn Fund (BCPFFABF). 
The Burn Fund not only helps the survivors of fires across British Columbia, they are also big on the education and prevention of fires and injuries due to fire.  Another thing the BC Burn Fund does is in the summer they run a camp for children who are burn survivors.
Their new project is the Burn Fund Center.  A brand new building at main Street and East 23rd Avenue in Vancouver will be an affordable place for caregivers to stay as their loved ones are being treated for their injuries at either Children’s Hospital of the Trauma and Plastics Unit at Vancouver General Hospital (VGH). There are a couple reasons we picked the BC Professional Fire Fighters Burn Fund.

The story is about Santa getting stuck in a chimney and a fire fighter saves him.
Later in the book they come across a chimney fire and the fire fighter puts out the fire so that Santa can safely deliver his presents.
Getting burned in a fire is often a devastating and life changing experience.  The BC Professional Burn fund does great work with burn survivors of all ages.  Please check out their website at burnfund.org for more information about the BC Professional Fire Fighters Burn Fund.

In order to be able to donate as much money as possible, we decided to do this crowd-funding. 
 
 Before the Book - Background StoryEvery Christmas since Nathan was born, we would go to the CityTV Breakfast Television FoodBank Friday in Vancouver.  The first time we went, we were interviewed by host Dawn Chubai.  When Nathan was just 1 year old, I started a company called Anything on a Clock.  Since then, whenever we went to FoodBank Friday, we would donate part proceeds of our November sales to the Food Bank.On December 4th, 2009, we went to the FoodBank Friday broadcast as we always had.  But this time was different.  Shortly after we arrived, a firetruck rolled in. Generally, Nathan is a bit groggy when we go to these events.  They start at 6:00 am and because we like to be there near the beginning, and then hang out for a bit, we usually leave the house around 5:00 am.  But when the fire truck arrived, Nathan got really excited.  Off camera, before our interview, Dawn Chubai asked Nathan why he was so excited.  Nathan being 3 1/2 years old at the time pointed to the firetruck and said “Super Heroes”.During our interview, Dawn asked Nathan again about the firefighters and he told Dawn that they were Super Heroes.  After our spot, they cut to Riaz Meghji who did an interview about the upcoming Santa Clause Parade.  Then it was the firefighter’s turn.  While Riaz was doling his thing, host Greg Harper asked if Nathan would like to join him at the firetruck for his segment. ...and so it all beganThat was the first time that Nathan connected his Super Heroes (firefighters) to Santa.  That evening when I tucked him into bed, I asked him for ideas for his bedtime story. He asked me “What would happen if Santa got stuck in a chimney?  Do you think firefighters would help them?” As Christmas grew closer, he would give different suggestions about how Santa got stuck in a chimney and how a firefighter came to his rescue.  Each night he would begin by giving a different scenario.  After a few nights I saw a pattern in our story telling so when he fell asleep each night, I would go to my computer and write down the story that we just made up. By Christmas, we had a lot of different adventures that Santa and his Super Hero would go on. They would all begin the same way; Santa would get caught in a chimney and a firefighter, his Super Hero, would pluck him out of the chimney. Later that year, I found the stories on my computer and thought that I would put it into a story book for Nathan.  I wrote out the story similar to what we have today and the next year I would read it to Nathan as we got closer to Christmas instead of making up the stories. Jump forward to the winter of 2014.  Christmas was approaching once again and Nathan asked me “When are we going to make this a real book?” I have been talking about it for the last few years but nothing came of it.  So I told him it was time we get it into print. And that is how we came up with a story about how a firefighter helped Santa when he got stuck in a Chimney. 

 
  Who want to be a Super Hero?


Getting a book illustrated, published and launched is quite a costly endeavor.  We have set up this fundraising to help pay for these expenses. We implore you to help fund this idea. The more money we can get from contributors to pay for these expenses, the more money we will have to give to the BC Professional Fire Fighters’ Burn Fund.

story:
It is not easy to explain the impact of publishing a piece of work which has been almost a year in the writing but to see the finished article in a Waterstones shop window, or on the shelves of a library is an experience which more people should have.

You, as a contributor, should take pride in the fact that you not only provided backing for the project but could also consider whether you could, yourself, replicate the feat. I have always been willing to help others to write and be published and will carry on with that philosophy.

When you open the book for the first time and see your name on the list of contributors, believe that your contribution is as valuable as any other resource which has gone into the final article, and trust that where you have provided the incentive other novels will follow.

The major risk in writing any piece of work is that it will go unnoticed and unappreciated. This is where the challenge of marketing takes the author to a new level. Building up a fan base is an immensely satisfying project, and to be told that your latest book kept someone up all night because they could not bear to put it down is a real thrill.

Of course, there is always a financial risk in committing time to any novel, and choosing the genre is a particularly important factor. I write what I know about or what I can reasonably find out. Stepping into the unknown is another risk, but the challenge of research more than makes up for it.

I’m never too proud to ask for help in areas where I have little no expertise and am fortunate to have a core of friends who possess the knowledge that I need. Again, the challenge is in learning new things which were, hitherto, beyond my reach.

·       The primary way to help is in taking part and backing the campaign in any of its levels, and these are provided on the web page. This can be as little as merely buying a copy.

·       In addition, you can spread the word amongst friends and colleagues who may be interested in the book and any of its predecessors. This will not only ensure that the book is published, but should also drive traffic to a range of platforms where my writing is showcased.

story:
Escape from Unemploymentville: True Stories of Bravery, Perseverance and Survival

Future updates and info can be found at: http://unemploymentville.com/book/

 

What happens to us when we are out of work (involuntarily) is different for each person.  There are common patterns, such as:

- The longer you are out of work, the more challenging both emotionally and financially

- People are often depressed, stressed out, or just not quite their usual selves

- Many people feel alone.  They go out less, wanting to save money or to avoid questions about what they are currently doing.

Sounds pretty grim, right?  That's why anyone struggling to find a job ought to hear from the people who have contributed to this book.  They will tell you that you can feel pretty down and out and still come back... even rise to a far better, happier position than before.

Everyone's story is unique and yet there are common themes:

Bravery: Some people went in new directions, changing careers, moving across the country, starting a business. 

Perseverance: Some folks just kept at it and didn't give up and eventually got a job 

Survival:  A few folks struggled to survive, losing their home, even facing eviction.  But they hung on and were able to make a new start. 

You can get a copy of these people's stories today and also get a finished copy of the book containing their stories, Escape from Unemploymentville: True Stories of Bravery, Perseverance and Survival.  Just check out the perks on the right. 

Or to learn more about why I created this book, read on.

My Story

It felt like all the world had some place important to go off to each morning -- and I did not.

I’d lost my job three months earlier and it bothered me that the world ran just as smoothly as it had when I was part of the work force.  My husband had meetings booked on his calendar from 9 to 5.  He was understandably frustrated that he had no time for lunch, or even a decent coffee break.  Every work day people wanted something from John, but somehow no one on the planet needed me to help them out.

Around month four of unemployment, I picked up a copy of Megan McArdle’s ‘The Up Side of Down, Why Failing Well Is the Key to Success.”  I felt like a failure, so I figured the best thing I could do was to learn to ‘fail well’.  I took heart in McArdle’s message that failing was okay and lots of failures were also okay, maybe even good.  But what really resonated with me, was hearing her say that when she finally received a job offer, she cried.  And that other than her wedding, these were the only tears of joy she ever shed as an adult. 

‘Wow,’ I thought.  “I get that. There is a lot of holding things together when you’re out of work, trying to convince yourself that you’re okay.  So, it’s not just me.”

I read other stories of unemployment and realized that unemployment is a bit like running on a hot day without any water to drink.  You might be able to manage it for a short time, but the longer you endure it, the more you will shut down and be unable to function normally.  Eventually it becomes life-threatening.

If you get rejected or disappointed enough times, it’s easy to start feeling like there is something wrong with you. You wonder what others have that you don’t. I wanted to hear from people who had been in my situation, survived with their sanity intact, and went on to better things. 

So, after I managed, finally, to get a real job – my current day job as a programmer and business analyst, I also worked on a project I dubbed Unemploymentville. 

At first it was simply the website, Unemploymentville.com, a forum and blog and then it became the book, Escape from Unemploymentville.

I put out some posts asking for people to contribute their stories of surviving unemployment.  The responses came from people on four different continents and in all walks of life.  A few entrepreneurs I sought out personally.  What happened to each person is unique, as is their telling of the story.  Some had jobs they were laid off from.  Others were recent graduates who were looking for their first job.  A few had health challenges that limited their job options. 

What was common was the message that I hope the book will offer to readers: You aren’t alone and this won’t last forever (even if it feels like it will). 

Escape from Unemploymentville Contains Stories of...

We’re preselling copies of Escape from Unemploymentville: True Stories of Bravery, Perseverence and Survival. The perks all include a copy of the current working draft and a copy of the completed book.  The money from the sales on Indiegogo will cover professional copyediting and layout.  But we’re after more than that…

We want to hear from our early readers.  We want you to tell us what is helpful in the book and what needs improving.  We have already incorporated changes based on reader reaction and we’ll continue to do so – with the goal being to make the book as helpful as possible.

So choose the perk (version of Escape from Unemploymentville) that is right for you from the options on the right-hand side of this page.

Thanks!
Anne

p.s. You may have noticed sometimes I talk about what 'I' am doing.  That’s me (Anne Emerick) and sometimes ‘we’, which means the team of contributing authors, some of whom also helped me create the Indiegogo campaign.

p.p.s. Several of our contributing authors have written books before.  Here are some of their books


Fired: Why Losing Your Job Is the Best Thing That Can Happen To You  - Stephanie Brown

Quotes for Achievement – Quotations, Stories and Advice from Great Achievers in Sports, Politics, Business and Life – Anne Emerick

No-Work Spanish Audio: Poster Girl - Anne Emerick

No-Work Spanish Audio: The Case of the Missing Poodle - Anne Emerick

No-Work Spanish Audio: Yaks March on Washington - Anne Emerick

The Day I Met Dr. Seuss - Anne Emerick

The Truth Is Out There (Tenet’s Tales Book 0)  - Brannon Hollingsworth

Cold Vengeance (Tenet’s Tales Book 1) - Brannon Hollingsworth

Ambush (Tenet’s Tales Book 3) - Brannon Hollingsworth

Prelude to Okolona - Brannon Hollingsworth

Robot Dad - Brannon Hollingsworth

Smart Job Hunting - (not yet released) - John Fugazzie

story:
In early 2017, my wife asked if I would join her on the Camino de Santiago, a pilgrimage across Northern Spain. It is a trek of roughly 450+ miles that will take over a month to complete.  Surprisingly, I intuitively replied "yes".

 I see the Camino as a creative journey even more than a spiritual or physical one. It has called to me as an artist.

 

Experiencing new and different things is what I "get" from travel. To help me process experiences, I keep a graphic journal in which I sketch the people, places and events I witness...

 I figure this pilgrimage is an opportunity to do so in a way as unique as the trek I will be undertaking.

The Camino will be unlike any previous trip because of its style and scope. I have been doing some background work to prepare me for it:

I've researched online, attended talks and gone on organized walks with other Pilgrims to get a better feel of what will be out there and how I will respond to it. But the truth is, I won't know until I am on the Camino.

 

I have created a working concept of this project. Below is a cover mock-up and some pre-travel sketches to give you an idea of how I envision the book's layout:

 

I invite you to join me on this creative journey. Through a whimsical prism, I will share with you my artistically bent view of this unique physical act of seeking/confirming spirituality.

story:
STORY: WHAT IS LITRO?

"I really like the fact that Litro supports emerging writers"

Kate Tempest, poet, spoken-word artist and playwright

Founded in 2005 by Eric Akoto, out of a passion for literature and a burning belief that writing can change the world, Litro has since developed into a leading literary arts platform with, at its core, an experienced editorial team and an host of talented contributors.

Before the advent of disposable ‘swipe’ culture the printed word really did have the power to change the world. Writers such as Chinua Achebe, Harriet Beecher Stowe, and George Orwell transformed our views; of ourselves and of our actions. We know that those transformative minds and talents are still out there. Well crafted prose still has the power to make us stop and think. We believe, in these dizzyingly changing times that now, more than ever, emerging literary talent needs a platform from which to be heard and absorbed.

“Litro was the start of good things for me, I have had a novel published and nominated for a few awards, I also went on to write a pilot for Channel 4’s comedy Lab series.”

Nikesh Shulka

Our monthly magazine, and website (www.litro.co.uk), gives that talent a platform.We publish a mix of emerging, established, and first time writers, side-by-side. We have helped kick-start the literary journeys of several now acclaimed writers, such as Eleanor Catton (2013 Man Booker Prize winner), Nikesh Shukla, Stuart Evers, Clare Wigfall, Lucie Whitehouse, Louise Stern, Sara Maitland to name but a few.  Their work sits alongside short stories by established authors like Naomi Alderman, Benjamin Zephaniah, Irvine Welsh, William Dalrymple, Abraham Verghese, Shashi Tharoor, and many more. This helps to introduce the readers of established writers to sparkling new authors, poets, and essayists.

IN 2018, WE WANT TO TAKE THINGS TO THE NEXT LEVEL

Having spent the last decade honing our platform and enhancing our skills in both literary publications and events, NOW is the time that we need your help to take Litro to the next level. With your support we can commission more original work, increase our monthly print run and encourage a cross-cultural exchange of ideas, starting by producing two World Series editions, showcasing this year the talent from India and Korea.

LITRO WORLD SERIES: VOICES FROM AROUND THE WORLD

Each year since 2011, Litro has published an annual World Series edition, focusing on contemporary talent, themes, and voices from a different part of the globe. Previous issues have shone a light on the creativity of Brazil, America, the Netherlands, Mexico, Cuba, Ghana and Nigeria, and India. In 2018 we hope to take our World Series even further by launching not just one but two new editions - both of which will be available as a perk to anyone pledging as little as £10.

February: Litro World Series: Translating India

Last year our India edition focused on English language prose from emerging and celebrated Indian writers. This year, our follow up edition will explore the diversity of Indian languages, including Bengali, Tamil, and Malayalam - and the rich culture of literature and thought they represent - with content produced by a range of established authors, translators, and a public call for submissions from new talent.

Guest edited by writer and politician Shashi Tharoor, the collection features writers such as Sangeeta Bandyopadhyay, Paul Zachariah, Benyamin, Perumal Murugan and K.R Meera.

Our hope is to publish an expanded edition twice the size of previous issues, and create an accompanying series of events in India and the UK, commencing in January 2018 at the world famous Jaipur Literature Festival.

May: Litro World Series - Korean Women Grab Back

The Korean publication showcases fiction by Korean women authors. It will be guest edited by 2016 Man Booker-winning translator (The Vegetarian), Deborah Smith, and features work by Han Kang (2016 Man Booker winner), Krys Lee, Janet Hong and more.

As in our India edition, language will be a key theme, with many writers coming from diaspora communities who write in languages other than Korean. There is much literature still to be discovered from this region, with very few works translated so far. This Litro World Series edition aims to correct this by bringing writers, artists and the thriving Korean community together with an audience of thousands.

How You Can Help

Our hope is to expand each of these World Series editions, to twice their normal format, creating a larger platform for more creative talent to shine. Alongside this, we wish to also expand our popular series of associated cultural events: talks, reading, music workshop, dance and much more. With these editions, Litro also hopes to encourage global empathy and understanding by providing a platform for cross-cultural exchange of voices and ideas.

You can help achieve this.

Impact

Not only does the World Series give readers the best contemporary writing from around the world, they also have a real impact on the authors, poets, and essayists we feature. After having submissions published in Litro’s 2015 Mexico Edition, Alvaro Enrique and Luis Miguel Aguilar were both awarded important literary prizes. The same was true of last year’s Ghana and Nigeria edition, which included work by Ayobami Adebayo who, only months later, was nominated for the Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction.

EXPANDING OUR PROJECT

Perhaps the most exciting thing about this crowdfunding campaign, is that it will allow us to open up the ownership of Litro to its members. We want to embrace our community, encouraging Litro members to send us their ideas on both the content and direction of the magazine, and commissioning more new work than ever before.

“Litro” - street slang for “lighter” in Brazil - is the perfect name for our work. Shining a light on literary talent. Illuminating our world through the diverse voices and experiences of its inhabitants. Igniting a fire for literature. We want to keep publishing the best new writing, but we need your help to expand our project.

"Since my stories were published in Litro, I’ve had four books published (one novel, one short story collection, one memoir and one poetry collection). I well remember the excitement of running around London, trying to track down a copy of the issues with my stories in them!"

Jonathan Pinnock

WHAT’S IN IT FOR ME?

Whatever you give you will have the reward of knowing that your pledge is helping to bring world changing thoughts and ideas by talented writers to a global audience.

Not enough?

Well thankfully, we also have some direct rewards to thank you for your contribution. Anyone pledging to support the crowdfunder can receive perks for as little as £5, but here’s a breakdown of what you can get in return for your pledge:

£5  - Certificate of thanks

£10 - a print World Series edition (either the India or South Korea magazine)

£20 - both print World Series editions + tote bag

£30 - 12 months digital subscription + tote bag

£50 - Annual print subscription to our monthly issue + digital access for 12 months

(2 world series editions and 10 monthly magazines)

£50 - Gift a 12 month subscription for a friend or family member

£75 - 12 month subscription + digital access + tote + T-shirt

£100 - Invitation to exclusive event in London, New York or India + tote bag + T-shirt + full print annual subscription

£250 - Your name listed in the edition + invitation for you and two guests to attend an exclusive event in London, New York or India + full print annual subscription + digital access + tote bag + T-shirt

£500 - Lifetime subscription

£750 - Lifetime subscription for both you + for a friend or family member

£1000 - Join Litro as a colleague + a full page ad in the magazine for an organisation of your choice + a lifetime subscription for yourself + lifetime gift subscription for a friend or family member. You’ll also get an invitation for you and two guests to attend an exclusive World Series event in London, New York or India + tote bag + T-shirt

As a patron to Litro, you will also be invited to meet the team at our offices in London's iconic Somerset House, where you will be treated to dinner by Litro editor-in-chief Eric Akoto.

LITRO PRODUCTION COSTS

Design

Copy

Translation into English

Publishing

Distribution

Events and launches in London and other UK Locations, working with UK Touring partners

Events beyond UK, including a global launch at India’s Jaipur Literature Festival

We believe, in these dizzyingly changing times that now, more than ever, emerging literary talent needs a platform from which to be heard and absorbed.“Litro was the start of good things for me, I have had a novel published and nominated for a few awards, I also went on to write a pilot for Channel 4’s comedy Lab series.”Nikesh ShulkaOur monthly magazine, and website (www.litro.co.uk), gives that talent a platform.We publish a mix of emerging, established, and first time writers, side-by-side. We have helped kick-start the literary journeys of several now acclaimed writers, such as Eleanor Catton (2013 Man Booker Prize winner), Nikesh Shukla, Stuart Evers, Clare Wigfall, Lucie Whitehouse, Louise Stern, Sara Maitland to name but a few.  Their work sits alongside short stories by established authors like Naomi Alderman, Benjamin Zephaniah, Irvine Welsh, William Dalrymple, Abraham Verghese, Shashi Tharoor, and many more. This helps to introduce the readers of established writers to sparkling new authors, poets, and essayists.IN 2018, WE WANT TO TAKE THINGS TO THE NEXT LEVELHaving spent the last decade honing our platform and enhancing our skills in both literary publications and events, NOW is the time that we need your help to take Litro to the next level. With your support we can commission more original work, increase our monthly print run and encourage a cross-cultural exchange of ideas, starting by producing two World Series editions, showcasing this year the talent from India and Korea.LITRO WORLD SERIES: VOICES FROM AROUND THE WORLDEach year since 2011, Litro has published an annual World Series edition, focusing on contemporary talent, themes, and voices from a different part of the globe. Previous issues have shone a light on the creativity of Brazil, America, the Netherlands, Mexico, Cuba, Ghana and Nigeria, and India. In 2018 we hope to take our World Series even further by launching not just one but two new editions - both of which will be available as a perk to anyone pledging as little as £10.February: Litro World Series: Translating IndiaLast year our India edition focused on English language prose from emerging and celebrated Indian writers. This year, our follow up edition will explore the diversity of Indian languages, including Bengali, Tamil, and Malayalam - and the rich culture of literature and thought they represent - with content produced by a range of established authors, translators, and a public call for submissions from new talent.Guest edited by writer and politician Shashi Tharoor, the collection features writers such as Sangeeta Bandyopadhyay, Paul Zachariah, Benyamin, Perumal Murugan and K.R Meera.Our hope is to publish an expanded edition twice the size of previous issues, and create an accompanying series of events in India and the UK, commencing in January 2018 at the world famous Jaipur Literature Festival.May: Litro World Series - Korean Women Grab BackThe Korean publication showcases fiction by Korean women authors. It will be guest edited by 2016 Man Booker-winning translator (The Vegetarian), Deborah Smith, and features work by Han Kang (2016 Man Booker winner), Krys Lee, Janet Hong and more.As in our India edition, language will be a key theme, with many writers coming from diaspora communities who write in languages other than Korean. There is much literature still to be discovered from this region, with very few works translated so far. This Litro World Series edition aims to correct this by bringing writers, artists and the thriving Korean community together with an audience of thousands.How You Can HelpOur hope is to expand each of these World Series editions, to twice their normal format, creating a larger platform for more creative talent to shine. Alongside this, we wish to also expand our popular series of associated cultural events: talks, reading, music workshop, dance and much more. With these editions, Litro also hopes to encourage global empathy and understanding by providing a platform for cross-cultural exchange of voices and ideas.You can help achieve this.ImpactNot only does the World Series give readers the best contemporary writing from around the world, they also have a real impact on the authors, poets, and essayists we feature. After having submissions published in Litro’s 2015 Mexico Edition, Alvaro Enrique and Luis Miguel Aguilar were both awarded important literary prizes. The same was true of last year’s Ghana and Nigeria edition, which included work by Ayobami Adebayo who, only months later, was nominated for the Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction.EXPANDING OUR PROJECTPerhaps the most exciting thing about this crowdfunding campaign, is that it will allow us to open up the ownership of Litro to its members. We want to embrace our community, encouraging Litro members to send us their ideas on both the content and direction of the magazine, and commissioning more new work than ever before.“Litro” - street slang for “lighter” in Brazil - is the perfect name for our work. Shining a light on literary talent. Illuminating our world through the diverse voices and experiences of its inhabitants. Igniting a fire for literature. We want to keep publishing the best new writing, but we need your help to expand our project."Since my stories were published in Litro, I’ve had four books published (one novel, one short story collection, one memoir and one poetry collection). I well remember the excitement of running around London, trying to track down a copy of the issues with my stories in them!"Jonathan PinnockWHAT’S IN IT FOR ME?Whatever you give you will have the reward of knowing that your pledge is helping to bring world changing thoughts and ideas by talented writers to a global audience.Not enough?Well thankfully, we also have some direct rewards to thank you for your contribution. Anyone pledging to support the crowdfunder can receive perks for as little as £5, but here’s a breakdown of what you can get in return for your pledge:£5  - Certificate of thanks£10 - a print World Series edition (either the India or South Korea magazine)£20 - both print World Series editions + tote bag£30 - 12 months digital subscription + tote bag£50 - Annual print subscription to our monthly issue + digital access for 12 months(2 world series editions and 10 monthly magazines)£50 - Gift a 12 month subscription for a friend or family member£75 - 12 month subscription + digital access + tote + T-shirt£100 - Invitation to exclusive event in London, New York or India + tote bag + T-shirt + full print annual subscription£250 - Your name listed in the edition + invitation for you and two guests to attend an exclusive event in London, New York or India + full print annual subscription + digital access + tote bag + T-shirt£500 - Lifetime subscription£750 - Lifetime subscription for both you + for a friend or family member£1000 - Join Litro as a colleague + a full page ad in the magazine for an organisation of your choice + a lifetime subscription for yourself + lifetime gift subscription for a friend or family member. You’ll also get an invitation for you and two guests to attend an exclusive World Series event in London, New York or India + tote bag + T-shirtAs a patron to Litro, you will also be invited to meet the team at our offices in London's iconic Somerset House, where you will be treated to dinner by Litro editor-in-chief Eric Akoto.LITRO PRODUCTION COSTSDesignCopyTranslation into EnglishPublishingDistributionEvents and launches in London and other UK Locations, working with UK Touring partnersEvents beyond UK, including a global launch at India’s Jaipur Literature Festival

story:
To understand is to achieve. To build systems that help others understand is to lead. 

Creative Leadership - for all AGES is my first book. Setting the stage for Creative Leadership to blossom in every soul.

AM Creactos (Arun Murthy Battula) https://www.linkedin.com/in/arunbattula/

Just as a showcase, I have published my first eBook. Available for purchase here. http://www.lulu.com/spotlight/creactos

Leadership will not and cannot be taught in a formal manner. Not because we do not have enough theories around the same, nor because we have not tried to do it already. 

Creative Leadership - for all AGES helps you grasp the few strands of knowledge, some of which can add to your strengths and some of them can add glitter and make you more charismatic. And may be in a shorter span of time. To help you help others sooner. 

My intention is to create a movement that is stronger than those I have already been part of in my development and growth as a leader. 

Key Take Away from the book: My sketches around associations of Heritage, Creativity, Strategy, Decisions, you and your enterprises.

At the core, a leader is continuously envisioning the future, creating the change that will enable that future to happen and at the pace it needs to happen, and still be there when it happens, to benefit from it. For some these benefits can be for themselves, and for others these benefits can be for the ones they envisioned the future for.

To begin with, I will use a few words to make sense or to tag a Leader and his actions that stand for leadership. 

Making Decisions both intime as well as to derive the most value
Being Adoptive or being at the center of the affairs to be on top of them
Sustaining the position
Continuously exploring newer options to reduce costs and efforts and make lives better

Dreaming or envisioning isn’t a core activity in my opinion. That’s something which happens automatically when someone realises what's unique about them in the entire set of ecosystems around them, works to nurture it and learns how to utilise it to create an advantage. That is identifying their potential and putting it to use.

Sounds very similar to what we already know. Yes. 

Only when someone is working around their uniqueness, can they be at the top, center and all around at the same time and sustaining it day by day. I will help you with this book.

I will do this by connecting you with multiple dimensions of perception, how to envision and create these for yourselves and others. And at times trying to delve into Heritage and Humanity itself.

That’s the reason it is difficult to follow or replicate a leader. And I believe is will never be possible to follow someone and become a leader, even when working in the same systems and for the same outcome.

Driven by Imagination, Collaborative research, Sensemaking, Growth mindset, Profit motive and the most recently acquired understanding on the value of care, based on the interactions and engagement with strategic initiatives over the past couple of decades in large corporates and new ventures across multiple industry verticals and geographies, working most of the time addressing recurring and persistent issues, experimenting and negotiation over constraints and in the process engaged most of the time with stakeholders from those in the top management to those still on top of affairs even without any position or recognition of any sort, I did try to make sense of what a Leader is. Or What leadership is. And what it takes to be creative and practical at the same time.

To understand is to achieve. To build systems that help others understand is to lead.

 

Why Fund: 

My equation 

P = TA^2

P = Possibility or Probability of success 
T = Your thinking and ideas that originate from your experiences built around your uniqueness
A = Your speedy Action to implement and realise your ideas

This book helps me create the channel to create and nurture the environments that can enhance the understanding of all those this set of knowledge reaches around the notions of

Creativity, Leadership, Strategy, Decision Making, Planning, Critical thinking, Intention, Purpose, Action, Enaction, Reaction, Proaction and Growth.

Your belief and support will help me negotiate time to finetune the set of frameworks, methodologies, narrations and access resources needed through travel and reflection in expert networks. 

This will also help me speed up the process of publication of the book and provide me with the much needed funds to further action on the 3 dimensions of futurescapes I have started sketching.


The large Impact you will create with a small support:

CREACTOS    www.creactos.com

  • is an acronym of Creative Action Outcomes, emphasizes the need for creative exploration, planned actions and execution for desired outcomes.
  • founded by me is a London based startup in Management Consulting, partnering globally drawn expertise for building and sustaining capabilities for creative economies.

Spheres of CREACTOS for Scoping Scaping and Sustaining Desired Outcomes. Click to Download

Your support will help me focus and make faster progress on the three Futurescapes we envisioned. 

AEME – Aesthetically Equated Mechanisms for Energy

We believe in achieving new balances in production, transmission and utilization of energy that’s possible by rethinking and weaving emerging technologies into new solutions that are harmonious, pleasing, non intrusive and safe.

AEME provides the platform for conceptualizing, collating and creating these new integrated mechanisms.


AURAMATIC 

Collaboration of Talent and Technology for enabling every individual glow Auramatically.

In a possible future, where repetitive tasks can and will easily be performed by intelligent machines, we are creating paths for individuals to identify and strengthen their unique abilities, deliver outcomes in the creative economies, drawing from the richness of cultural heritage.


THOUGHT SQUARE

An effort to create awareness on adaptable frameworks and solutions for psychological well-being of Humanity. Intention is to be more than a beacon of guidance and be part of building the behaviors needed for Happy and fulfilling lives in the future.


Looking forward to working with you, for you, or just for that future all of us love to see happen.

Thanks and Regards,

AM Creactos 
(Arun Murthy Battula)

http://www.creactos.com

https://www.linkedin.com/in/arunbattula/

story:
My Story

A teenage half-faerie falls for the human girl she's supposed to be spying on. In a land where dragon eggs grow on trees and Dreaming is illegal, the lesbian faerie tale lives on. (The beautiful drawing that accompanies this campaign is an early piece of fan art by the ever talented solaert!)

A trans boy with a familiar name -- Peter Pan, anyone? -- is hopelessly in love with a nonbinary pilot who's about to die in a pointless war: so, naturally, Peter programs a holomatrix called Neverland to save them. 

My debut novels -- LUNAV and LOST BOY, FOUND BOY -- are dropping this March through NineStar Press. 

And I'd love to bring these books -- and the stories behind their creation -- to your hometown.

Since the books got contracted, I've been inundated with requests for a book tour from young people who feel like these novels can give them some of the representation they deserve.

I'm already slated to take my books on tour from NYC to Oakland, San Diego, and Las Vegas (ClexaCon 2018, baby!) in early April -- and, living and loving on an adjunct professor income, I need your help getting there and beyond.

I've had requests from young queer folks to bring my book talks, readings, and workshops in hometowns ranging from Chicago to Melbourne; but I can only give the book tour these kids deserve with your help.

What I Need & What I Want to Give You

If I were Sadie (my main character in LUNAV), I could fly to All The Places.

If I were Mir (the nonbinary pilot in LOST BOY, FOUND BOY), I could also fly to All The Places; but in a ship instead of with wings like Sadie's.

Alas.

While I may have places to crash with lovely readers and friends in certain cities, flights and food and the costs of exhibiting at book cons and festivals -- and those random travel expenses that you never expect but always come up -- need to get covered.

Most of the funds you contribute will go directly toward my travel expenses for my book tour; the only funds that won't go right into paying for flights and trains will go right back to you!

Yep. You read it right: while most of the money will go directly to supporting my ability to make as many quality stops on my book tour as possible, some of it will go toward thanking you for helping make it a reality.

Some of you -- just check out the perks on the sidebar!! -- will receive shout-outs on social media to express my gratitude. Some of you will receive inscribed copies of LUNAV and digital copies of LOST BOY, FOUND BOY. Others will get signed bookmarks and limited edition LUNAV and LOST BOY merch, and/or lesbian faerie sweatshirts (because... who doesn't want lesbian faerie sweatshirts)? While my endless gratitude that you'll all get is, of course, free of charge, production and shipping of your goodies aren't: so, some of the money will go right back to you, in that respect.

Even if I don't hit my final goal, every bit that I do raise will go toward expanding my book tour: and truly, no sweatshirt (no matter how awesome) can ever thank you enough for that.

Why a Book Tour?

Along my writing journey so far -- whether it's through creating an almost absurd amount of Supergirl fan fiction on tumblr or through the program I'm setting up with my publisher to get queer young adult books into the hands of LGBTQIA+ young adults who can't afford them -- I keep hearing so many stories about the importance of being represented in the fiction we consume.

I weep along with the rest of you when lesbian characters are pointlessly killed off on television, and I head to the gym to pump out my rage when yet another trans kid is reduced to a stereotype in the media. We deserve fiction where we thrive; where we struggle, too, yes, but where we know we will ultimately be... happy.

We deserve multi-dimensional queer characters -- including love interests -- and I strive to bring that to my readers every day. My writing is not perfect, and never will be; but I will always keep trying to improve. 

Part of that journey is this inaugural book tour: meeting each other -- readers and writers alike -- can only make our community stronger. Book talks, readings, and workshops can only serve to strengthen the creative and cathartic communities that we need in this world. I am humbled to play even a small role in these communities; and it would be an honor to take this book tour as far and wide as I can.

My online readership is strong, and it is worldwide: bringing these communities together in person would be the opportunity of a lifetime, and these book releases are the perfect time to start.

I would absolutely love it if you'd join me -- us -- on this journey.

More Ways You Can Help

Are you one of those young folks I've been talking about? One of those delightful readers and writers who've suggested locations for my book tour but for whom even a dollar contribution is too much right now?

Or, heck, is rent just too much this month?

I totally feel you.

Money isn't the only way to spread the Launch Love: monetary contribution or not, I would be absolutely honored to have you join my Launch Team!

As part of this team, you can spread the word about the books themselves, and you can spread the word about this campaign. Indiegogo (this fine site you've been reading!) has share tools that you can use, too: the more proverbial noise you make about the books and this book launch campaign, the better. 

However you decide to help, you have my unending gratitude and love; however you decide to help, you are of the awesome.

Keep being fabulous; in other words, keep being you.

And hopefully, I'll see you on the tour.

story:
If you read, write, publish, or sell books about Texas, Lone Star Literary Life is for you.

WE COVER THE TEXAS LITERARY SCENE like no one else, week in and week out. Since 2015, we’ve given Texas authors, booksellers, libraries, publishers, and readers a trusted platform of their own. With shrinking coverage devoted to books in mainstream media — and most of that focused on the same handful of national bestsellers — where were Texas authors to get noticed, and where were Texas readers to discover the books they crave? We’ve stepped up to make sure the Lone Star State doesn’t lose touch with its rich literary heritage, and that Texas books get their due.

NOW, WE REALIZE you don’t read only about Texas, all the time. But when you do, you want to know about emerging writers, fresh takes on Texas history and culture, great events, and the newest releases from your longtime favorites. And we know you want opportunities to experience the literary scene, whether your interests run to signings, slams, or seminars.

As we head into our fourth year, we need your help to take Lone Star Lit to the next level.

“You rocked our little world — yay, we finally have our own publication!
A very thrilling moment.”  — SARAH BIRD

 

Here’s how far we’ve come . . . 

SINCE LAUNCHING THREE YEARS AGO with the backing of some terrific supporters, Lone Star Lit has:  

  • reviewed hundreds of Texas-related books in all genres —more professional reviews than in any other media outlet — showcasing more than 50 different publishers, including national houses and the majority of Texas-based presses
  • listed an average of a hundred book-and-author schedules each week in the state’s only comprehensive calendar of book events
  • interviewed more than 150 Texas writers, from best-sellers to debut authors
  • hosted more than 100 authors on Lone Star Book Blog Tours
  • shone a spotlight on thousands of libraries, booksellers, and venues with notices, advertisements, stories, news briefs, and events listings
  • provided resource directories of bookstores, writing groups, and more
  • charged readers $0 for content. Nada. Zilch.

“This is what ought to have been there all along.”
 — STEPHEN HARRIGAN

 

Lone Star Lit’s reach and impact

AT THE OUTSET OF 2018, our base of friends and followers continues to grow. But because the influence of literature — and literary news — is much greater than audience numbers alone, you’ll find our reviews quoted widely and our news shared far beyond the state's borders.

But since you're wondering about audience anyhow: 

30,000 monthly uniques on our website • 10,000 on Facebook • 3,700 on Twitter • 1,400 on LinkedIn • 475 on Instagram • 7,500 in our opt-in email database

We're honored to bring you reviews and news from such stellar contributors as Rod Davis, Carlton Stowers, Angelina LaRue, Si Dunn, and Chris Manno, plus, every week, Glenn Dromgoole’s TEXAS READS column and featured reviews by NBCC critic Michelle Newby (whose TexasBookLover blog was named one of the state's Top 50 in 2017).

“We were really pleased . . .
[Texas readers] were a community that hadn’t really been drawn together.
 — ELIZABETH CROOK

 

Where we’ll go from here, with your help

WE'RE THRILLED TO INTRODUCE some new ventures this year.

  • In May, our weekly Lone Star Listens interviews will hit the shelves in book form, a compilation that will provide a valuable learning tool for apprentice writers and a one-of-a-kind archive of contemporary Texas literary life. Featuring a compelling overview of Texas letters by novelist and teacher Clay Reynolds, Lone Star Listens will shed light on the processes, inspirations, and achievements of Texas writers, with uniquely personal insights. (It’s one of our top perks for this campaign, too!)
  • In 2018 we also look to go live with Texas Book Talk, taking our content into the audiosphere for those of you who enjoy listening via podcast and Internet radio.
  • Finally, we’ll update our annual Top Texas Bookish Destinations this spring in book form as well as online. Look for Literary Texas in a bookstore near you, or support this campaign and be one of the first to have a copy mailed to your door.

“Thank you; keep on doing that good work!”
— DAVE PARSONS, Texas Poet Laureate 2011

 

Come and Fund It.

WE PLEDGE TO CONTINUE the kind of quality journalism that Texans have grown to love from us — for free — and we’re asking our readers and stakeholders to chip in a bit.

Just as with any newspaper, all this takes money. We continue to enhance our technology and grow our reach, while keep advertising rates affordable. We pay our reviewers and contributors fairly. We send correspondents into the field to cover news. We edit and produce richly featured content every week. We design ads, blog tours, emails, social media, and other tools that help promote Texas books.

We survey readers each summer to discover their Favorite Texas Bookstores, and we work with publishers to bring you our lists of Kids’ Summer Reads, Top Texas Fiction and Nonfiction of the Year, and Holiday Gift Guide.

Your contribution will keep great features like these coming. Thanks in advance, y’all!

WE COVER THE TEXAS LITERARY SCENE like no one else, week in and week out. Since 2015, we’ve given Texas authors, booksellers, libraries, publishers, and readers a trusted platform of their own. With shrinking coverage devoted to books in mainstream media — and most of that focused on the same handful of national bestsellers — where were Texas authors to get noticed, and where were Texas readers to discover the books they crave? We’ve stepped up to make sure the Lone Star State doesn’t lose touch with its rich literary heritage, and that Texas books get their due.

NOW, WE REALIZE you don’t read only about Texas, all the time. But when you do, you want to know about emerging writers, fresh takes on Texas history and culture, great events, and the newest releases from your longtime favorites. And we know you want opportunities to experience the literary scene, whether your interests run to signings, slams, or seminars.
As we head into our fourth year, we need your help to take Lone Star Lit to the next level.
“You rocked our little world — yay, we finally have our own publication!A very thrilling moment.”  — SARAH BIRD

listed an average of a hundred book-and-author schedules each week in the state’s only comprehensive calendar of book events
interviewed more than 150 Texas writers, from best-sellers to debut authors
hosted more than 100 authors on Lone Star Book Blog Tours
shone a spotlight on thousands of libraries, booksellers, and venues with notices, advertisements, stories, news briefs, and events listings
provided resource directories of bookstores, writing groups, and more
charged readers $0 for content. Nada. Zilch.

story:
Considering the overwhelmingly positive response to the black and white edition of Cupid's Farewell Christmas, we are thrilled and grateful that our quirky holiday tale about daring to be yourself has already touched so many people.

We believe this funny, fresh take on Christmas—one that resonates with people of all ages and backgrounds—should be delivered, in its fully realized vision, to people grown tired of recycled stories and the hyper-commercialization of one of the world's most cherished holidays.

Our goal is simple: to transform the illustrations from the black and white 2017 edition into full color and deliver a finished book that becomes an enduring holiday season classic.

 

The first edition, black and white version of Cupid's Farewell Christmas has nearly 60 illustrations, the majority of which still need to be completed to make the full-color 2018 edition available for widespread distribution next holiday season.

The artistic standards that we have set for the project are high, and the vision for the final book is as a keepsake gift of the utmost quality: one that may be read, shared, and enjoyed year after year.

Our goal for this stage of the project is to raise $5,000, the majority of which will be used to support Sonny as he completes the colorization of the original images from the black and white edition of the book.

The other funds will be dedicated to optimizing our social media campaign, Indiegogo fees, and all of the perks that a happy Santa will deliver to all of those supporters on his Nice List.

 

The colorization of the first edition illustrations will be digital, and each image will require a similar degree of attention so that each one evokes the nostalgia of a classic painting, like the book's cover. Considering this, the greatest challenge to having a full-color book ready for publication and widespread distribution in 2018 is adequate time and funding. Unlike the two-year rendering of the black and white edition, however, coloring the original illustrations of Cupid's Farewell Christmas will require approximately 3-4 months of focused, dedicated work. With sufficient funding, the illustrator, Sonny Quinn, is committed to the time required and eager to complete the project.

 

181 years delivering toys has Santa Claus ready to call it quits. He’s burnt-out, saddled with hemorrhoids, and needs to carry a shotgun to do the dangerous business of climbing down chimneys. In fact, Santa's ready to quit “this wicked-bitch of a route” and retire somewhere warm, like Boca Raton, or Las Vegas.

Santa’s troubles only magnify when his favorite reindeer—the beloved, but rebellious Cupid—runs off on Christmas Eve.

Now facing a world on edge and a runaway reindeer, what's a not-so-jolly Saint Nick to do on what just might be his last Christmas?

 

The gifts and perks for getting on Santa's Nice List and supporting Cupid's Farewell Christmas include:

  • Personalized animated holiday eCard from Evan & Quinn;
  • Signed first edition copies of Cupid's Farewell Christmas;
  • Signed and personalized first edition copies of Cupid's Farewell Christmas;
  • Signed and personalized full-color copies of Cupid's Farewell Christmas;
  • "Santa's Bagged" tote bags;
  • 5-packs of "It always feels best when we give" Humping Reindeer Christmas cards;
  • "Humping Reindeer" Christmas tree ornaments;
  • Contributor's name(s) featured on the 2018 edition "Acknowledgments" page;
  • Signed and framed 12"x18" prints of "Santa's gotta do what he's gotta do;"
  • Original art: Signed and framed original concept sketches;
  • Two original paintings;
  • And more.

The creative team, Cliff Evan & Sonny Quinn, are both graduates from Columbia University's School of the Arts.

The author, Clifford Evan, is a freelance writer and college instructor whose novel Delivered was released in paperback in 2013.

The illustrator, Sonny Quinn, is a painter, a storyboard artist, and the director of the documentary film A Light in the Dark, the Art and Life of Frank Mason, an official selection of the Newport Beach and Big Apple Film Festivals.

 

Santa is, well…Santa.

 

The greatest challenge to having full color book ready for publication and widespread distribution in 2018 is adequate time and funding. Unlike the two-year rendering of the black and white edition, however, coloring the original illustrations of Cupid's Farewell Christmas will require approximately 3-4 months of focused, dedicated work. With sufficient funding, the illustrator Sonny Quinn is committed to the time required and eager to complete the project.

Original art takes time to complete. Many of the world's most famous and beloved illustrated books, first rendered as original paintings, have taken years to produce. The black and white illustrations for Cupid's Farewell Christmas were each hand-drawn in pencil before being digitally revised. That was the most challenging stage of the project. and took nearly two years to go from the roughest of sketches to the published first edition. We anticipate that it will take Sonny 3-4 months to color these original illustrations. Getting funded now, though, will give us the opportunity to get you a black and white version for this Christmas and then the full-color edition for next year!

 

Even if you cannot contribute financially to Cupid's Farewell Christmas, you can still help us to reach our project goals of making the book a new holiday classic by spreading the holiday cheer and letting your friends and family know about our campaign on social media. Just a couple of clicks and shares on Indiegogo will get you right onto Santa's Nice List!

Thank you and silver bells of holiday cheer to all!

Clifford Evan & Sonny Quinn

Olympia is sending its 3rd team to the National Poetry Slam! During their biweekly practices, team members are writing, editing, and perfecting their performances all summer to bring their best to a national stage this August in Denver. Taylor Bereiter, Rachel Greene, Brian McCracken and Dan Evans are four talented, queer, social and environmental justice-minded poets with a lot to say. Your contribution can amplify their voices to a wider audience and promote a rich poetic culture in Olympia as they bring their experiences back to their community. Supporting this fundraiser also contributes to their artistic and personal growth by giving them access to this vibrant international artistic community.

Poets on Team Olympia earned their spot by taking the stage again and again during Olympia People’s Mic’s competitive slam season. Founded by Old Growth Poetry Collective in 2014, Olympia People's Mic is a weekly poetry show featuring an open-mic and slam at Ben Moore's Restaurant every Thursday evening. Poets and audience share a safe and inclusive all-ages space for artistic dialog. Each week, Olympia People's Mic hosts a new, riveting, live featured performance from spoken word artists from all around North America. In addition to sending its third team to the National Poetry Slam, Olympia People’s Mic sends representatives to the Women of the World Poetry Slam (WOWPS) and the Individual World Poetry Slam (IWPS) annually.

Old Growth Poetry Collective and Olympia People's Mic is a DIY poetry community funded entirely by donation. At our weekly show, we charge $0-5 sliding scale so that our space is accessible to everyone regardless of income. This meets our week-to-week needs but is not enough to send teams to three annual international poetry events. To do this, we rely completely on donations from our friends, family, and community.

To get to the National Poetry Slam we need to raise $3,000. This will cover the cost of airfare and a team hotel room. We are hosting local benefit shows and soliciting local businesses in addition to our online campaign. If we do not meet our goal we are still heading to Denver! Poets have committed to covering any unfunded costs out of their own almost-empty bank accounts. If we do make our initial goal, any additional funds will go toward supporting our venue and sending representatives to other international events throughout the year.

THANK YOU for taking the time to read this and watch our video. We hope that you will donate and share this campaign via e-mail and social media with your family, friends and community. Be sure to come to Olympia People's Mic, including our Team Olympia send-off show August 3rd.

To stay up-to-date with Old Growth Poetry Collective events you can like us on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, visit our website, or sign up for our newsletter. Thanks a bunch!

story:
So you know how one day you’re a sprightly young twenty something, ambling your way through life visiting exotic holiday destinations and spending all your not very hard earned cash on partying with not a care in the world? You think you’re going to stay that way for ever right? Only one day you find yourself living in the suburbs with two kids and a mortgage, and you realise that forty is really right around the corner. Do you accept your fate, let your belt out a notch or two, strap yourself into your economical family car and enjoy the rather sedentary ride through middle age? Or maybe you stop in your tracks, take stock of your settled ways, and try to find a way to put the fun back in.

As I hurtled towards the big four-0, I met a lady in her seventies who consciously chose to live an abundant life, filled with family, friends and activities she relished. Her energy put me to shame, and encouraged me to reflect on the contented, yet settled nature of the current stage of my life. I needed to put a little fun back in. I decided to have a go at abundant living myself. In the year I turned forty, I would do forty things for the first time.   

The challenge would see me appear on a BBC game show, audition for Britain's got Talent and dye my sensible hair bright pink. I told each story along the way, explaining why I had chosen each ‘first’, recalling some memories stirred up as I prepared for and completed each one. I wrote honestly and humorously about my endeavours, my triumphs and my spectacular failures. 

Some highlights of the challenges include 

• Picking up my violin after twenty years, and busking on the Royal Mile, Edinburgh. My son saw that I was struggling so came to join me with his ukelele. It didn’t help - we got moved on after twenty minutes. 

• Driving a tank in Stirlingshire. I saw it as my personal mission to rattle the nerves of my teenage driving instructor. 

• Setting off thousands of pounds worth of fireworks at a stately home for a celebrity wedding. 

• Killing and eating a lobster named Jemima. 

What results is my first book '40 is my Forte', a genuine and amusing portrayal of a middle aged woman attempting to reclaim the more exciting feel of her youth, and balancing that with the restrictions that family life entails. 

I'm now hoping to get my book published. The money raised here will go towards paying an editor to check over my suspect grammar and spelling, a graphic designer to come up with an eye catching cover and of course the printer to actually, you know, print the books.

My manuscript is complete. I have an editor on board, graphic designer lined up and a book press ready to hit 'print'. I've never done this before, but I have a good team around me, experienced in the world of publishing, and self publishing, and I'm confident they will steer me in the right direction.

The timescale is a bit of a best guess at this stage. I will endeavour to publish my book at the earliest opportunity once funding has been secured, but I would imagine there are a number of variables, so there is a bit of educated guesswork here.

My PR machine (AKA Facebook & Twitter) is ready and waiting to go and I am already embracing the art of self promotion. The launch promises to be spectacular. I've already heard mention of vol au vents. What could possibly be better!

story:
Help us accurately report news on Syria

If you read about the Syrian conflict in the mainstream press, Syrian reporters are largely absent from the narrative. Yet their knowledge and firsthand experience of the situation is much greater. SyriaWire aims to change this by giving Syrian reporters, all of whom are also asylum seekers in Europe, a platform to cover what is happening in their country. 

The Syria conflict affects everyone of us and is in dire need of better understanding and coverage. SyriaWire can provide this.

In September, SyriaWire went live on a trial basis to give readers and donors an idea of what they are backing. You can take a look here: www.syriawire.com

But in October, with your donations, our reporting will officially begin with a full team of journalists; the content will be better, broader and multimedia in nature. 

Back this project and you’ll help to create: 

  • Daily reports from inside Syria - not just spot coverage
  • Informative, multimedia maps and infographics on different groups fighting in the war
  • Humanitarian coverage of civilian casualties otherwise forgotten in press reports
  • News updates and personal stories from refugees in Europe
  • Timely analysis and reporting that adds crucial context to the conflict, the refugee crisis and international news

Your support allows us:

  • To produce independent and reliable news on the conflict with the help of informed sources both inside and outside of Syria 
  • To hire additional Syrian journalists, enabling us to cover more stories
  • To provide work opportunities for Syrian refugee reporters
  • To compensate the Syrians inside the country working to report the news
  • To sustain SyriaWire as we wait for other official grants and funding

The Syrian journalists and how it works:

Every SyriaWire reporter is Syrian and an asylum seeker in Europe, having fled the civil war in Syria in order to be safe. Each journalist will cover a key region in Syria, the region they themselves are from. By doing it this way, Syrian journalists that really understand the situation and have a network of sources on the ground, both professional and personal, can report objectively from the safety of European soil. 

Journalistic independence is impossible from inside Syria, as the situation requires journalists in the country to take sides. Whether a reporter in Syria chooses to work in a government-controlled area, a rebel stronghold or other, their ability to report objectively is impeded for fear of repercussions, be it death, arrest, harassment or disappearances. 

SyriaWire offers a solution to this challenge. However, for their continued safety and that of their families and friends still in Syria, the Syrians involved in this project must remain anonymous. 

How the idea came to be:

My name is Natasha Bowler and I’m a journalist and documentary filmmaker specialising in the Middle East, human rights and the refugee crisis. I have reported and made documentaries for publications including The Guardian, Foreign Policy, Reuters and more.

Earlier this year, I spent several months volunteering with the refugees in Greece, and reporting on the crisis. During this time, I got to know a lot of Syrians, many of whom told me stories from the conflict that English-language media was not reporting. This is how I got the idea for SyriaWire, and began working with Syrian refugees in creating the website. 

Prior to this, I was a Staff Reporter and the Deputy-Editor of a publication called IranWire, which like SyriaWire, works with Iranian refugees living in the diaspora to cover Iran-focused news. We decided to do the same for Syria.

Other ways you can help:

We appreciate not everyone can help us financially. But if you think the project is a good one, please help us spread the word about SyriaWire by sharing it within your social networks. That is a huge help in itself! 

We promise to work hard and report objectively. But we need your support to do so. We truly appreciate any help you can give.

Thank you so much from the SyriaWire team!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Miodrag Ilic, and I am owner and Chef Editorial of well know culinary web portal in Serbia: Recepti i Kuvar online.

We want to create a bilingual cookbook containing traditional recipes of national Serbian cuisine including our cultural, health and historical aspects, so as to save the recipes of our grandmothers and great-grandmothers from oblivion.

What We Need & What You Get

The money we will get as support for this project, will be used for preparing, design, translation and print of this book. The number of our associates who are unselfishly engaged in preparing this book is large: they share their ideas with us, their photos, recipes from their families' old cookbooks...

The Impact

When someone says “sarma” , “vanilice”, “baklava”, “pogača”, “zeljanica”, “pihtije”... in Serbia, it immediately refreshes one's memories and the relation with tradition. The tradition of Serbian cuisine is very old. One of the oldest Serbian cookbook was Srbski kuvar by Krusedol Monastery monk Jerotej Draganovic, published in 1865, in the Old Slavic language. One of the most educated people living at the end of 19th and the beginning of the 20th century, Sima Trojanovic (who was ethnologist),  published a book called Old Serbian Dishes and Beverages in 1896.

The list of such old collections of recipes, cookbooks, books on customs is very long. These books represent our primary motivation and driving force to start and finish this project underlain by the following idea: to preserve a part of the culinary and cultural heritage that came from our ancestors. In this book, you will find many old dishes which are now on the verge of being forgotten, which can be very rarely ordered in restaurants and are seldom prepared even within the family circles.

This project is recognized and supported by Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Serbia, as very important step in order to preserve a part of the culinary and cultural heritage:

„A traditional recipe of the local Serbian cuisine is an important part of the intangible cultural heritage of each nation. The list of elements of the intangible cultural heritage of the Republic of Serbia, in addition to traditional crafts, folk tradition, ethno songs and dances, with naive painting Slovaks, there are Belmuz meal, traditional production of Pirot cheese, pazarske mantije meal (traditional method of preparation). These elements are vital to the preservation of national identity, and are also an integral part of various tourism offers.

This project is recognized and supported by Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Serbia, as very important step in order to preserve a part of the culinary and cultural heritage:

„A traditional recipe of the local Serbian cuisine is an important part of the intangible cultural heritage of each nation. The list of elements of the intangible cultural heritage of the Republic of Serbia, in addition to traditional crafts, folk tradition, ethno songs and dances, with naive painting Slovaks, there are Belmuz meal, traditional production of Pirot cheese, pazarske mantije meal (traditional method of preparation). These elements are vital to the preservation of national identity, and are also an integral part of various tourism offers.

Why is Serbian cuisine so specific?

Because it represents a unique collection of cultural and culinary, national and historical diversity that emerged in the past centuries... The mixture of Turkish, Greek, Bulgarian, Hungarian and other cuisines makes it rich and distinctive.

What is the target audience of this book?

Everyone! Tourists, whether they plan to spend their holidays in Serbia or are on a business trip to Serbia. Diaspora, so that anyone who is “warmed by the sun of another sky” remind themselves of some of the forgotten dishes and “feed” their nostalgia, as well as to give with great proud a copy of the book as a gift to a dear person in order to show what country they came from. Experienced chefs, as well as inexperienced beginners who will have the opportunity to put their knowledge on trial, especially after reading this book.

Risks & Challenges

Our project is fully transparent and with your help we not expecting any risks and challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, support our project. Please share this story, and enjoy reading and cooking!

story:
My name is Christiana Gaudet. Since 1993 I have been a successful full-time professional tarot reader.

Over the past 25 years I have enjoyed many achievements in my career, including being the “Resident Psychic” of radio stations like Q105 in New London, CT and Jammin 107.7 in Ledyard, CT. Most recently, I was named “Tarosophist of the Year” for 2016 by the Tarosophy Tarot Association, the world’s largest international tarot organization.

In 2010, my book "Fortune Stellar" was published by Jupiter Gardens Press. Over the past seven years, this popular book has helped many tarot professionals achieve success in creating their unique business.

I was surprised that "Fortune Stellar" also became a favorite of astrologers, massage therapists and other solopreneurs who happen to use tarot as a personal tool.

In August 2016, Jupiter Gardens went out of business, and Fortune Stellar went out of print. Almost every day since then people have reached out to me, asking where they can get a copy of this unique book.

In a world where there is very little support for those called to work professionally with the cards, Fortune Stellar helps individuals use tarot to create the unique business model that works for them.

Drawing on my quarter-century of successful full-time tarot work, Fortune Stellar offers a blueprint for success at a time when tarot is more popular than ever worldwide, and when we have access to affordable technology that makes running a worldwide business easy.

The Second Edition of Fortune Stellar will include copious author notes detailing things I've learned in the past seven years. Advances in our culture and technology, such as social media, the "sharing economy", and the ability to work online are just some of the new topics that I am adding to the Second Edition.

I am also adding a new section that includes profiles of full-time professional readers from all over the world. Readers will learn, not only from my experience, but also from theirs.

The expenses of self-publishing a great book are not exorbitant, but I need your help to do it the right way.

I am hiring two tarot professionals to help me; Steven Bright will design my new book cover, and Mary Ellen Collins will be my editor.

Supporters of this campaign have the ability to pre-order Fortune Stellar and receive it as soon as it is available.

Some levels of support include the ability to receive the updated edition of Tarot Tour Guide, and my brand new tarot book, both expected to publish before the end of 2017.

There are also a limited number of opportunities to study one-on-one with me, and to  allow me to mentor you in growing your tarot business.

My entire professional life has happened because of the support of people who care about tarot and its wisdom. Please continue to support this work, and let the Second Edition of Fortune Stellar come to life!

Should I fall short of fundraising goals the project will continue, and supporters will receive their perks.

Should I exceed fundraising goals I will use any additional funds on the Second Edition of Tarot Tour Guide.
